metadata.title: How to split the traffic in an A/B Test | by Aditya Rustgi | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to split the traffic in an A/B Test
metadata.description: Choosing whether to split the test when a user lands on your website vs. when they get exposed to your test can significantly impact how long your test takes to complete.

all_paragraphs: When I started my A/B testing, there were several things that I understood at a superficial level (stuff I had read in books or online videos). However, I was fortunate to have colleagues that helped me understand these ideas intuitively, including basic concepts behind test design. I wrote about this in another article titled ‘The intuition behind A/B Testing — A Primer for New Product Managers.’
Once I got past the basics, other techniques helped me optimize the design of my tests. In this article, I will talk about one of these techniques — Test Exposure.
Understanding “Test Exposure” is essential because it helps design the test in a manner that can help you get to results faster.

We’ll start with a simple example. Imagine your product is a website www.merchant.com that lets users buy furniture. The following diagram explains how the user may navigate through the various sections of the website.

X refers to the total number of users who arrive on your website on any of the landing pages. Y is the number the users who visit on the shopping cart page. Z is the number of people who click Checkout on the shopping cart page and enter the checkout process.
Let’s assume that the following numbers reflect the value of X, Y, and Z.
X = 12,000 unique users per day (averaged over the last month)
Y = 1,200 users per day (or 10% of all landing users add something to the cart and visit their shopping cart)
Z = 400 users per day (3.33% of all users who visit the website end up buying something. Alternatively, 33.33% of the users who start the checkout process end up buying the item.)

By moving the checkout button to the right, we can increase the conversion of our website by 10%, because people who may not be converting because they can’t find the checkout button will not easily find the checkout button.

To answer the previous question, let’s evaluate the size of the sample set you will need. To answer this question, we will use Evan Miller’s excellent A/B testing sample size calculator. We shall use the standard value of the significance threshold of 0.05 and a power of 80%
The sample size for Option 1
What this is saying is that you will need 46,224 users per variation or approximately 92,448 unique users entering the website.
The sample size for Option 2

What this is saying is that you will need 3,161 per variation or 6,322 users entering the shopping cart. If 10% of all users who visit the website end up in the shopping cart, then to get 6,322 users onto the shopping cart, you will need 63,220 users entering the site.
Compared to Option 2, Option 1 requires 46.23 % more users. Option 2 is superior because it detects the same outcome faster, thereby speeding up the tests.
When I first identified this issue, my reaction was the same.
How could just changing the way you allocate users into the variant and control bucket change the number of test participants when everything else stays the same?

To find out why I did some online research, and here is what I learned. To understand this, you have to map out the user flow and identify the users who fall into the two buckets of ‘converting’ and ‘non-converting users.’
Note that the group of people who don’t convert is composed of people who enter the checkout flow as well as people who don’t. Evan Miller calls the latter ‘Dead Weight.’

Test exposure refers to the concept of splitting your users into control and variant groups at the right moment in the user journey. The right moment is when the user would see the altered design had it rolled out 100%.

I want to give my colleague Stas Blade from VRBO credit for introducing me to this particular concept, and to Evan Miller for his excellent sample size calculator and his thought leadership on the topic of A/B testing.

About Me: Aditya Rustgi is a product leader with over 15 years of product and technology leadership experience in Multi-sided Marketplaces and B2B Saas business models in eCommerce and Travel Industry. Most recently, he was a director of product management at VRBO, an Expedia Company.
